pull_request.title: Techdocs 404 analytics event
pull_request.body:
## Hey, I just made a Pull Request!

We're wanting to do some improvements, but first we want to get a baseline of how often a user ends up on a techdocs page that doesn't exist.

This PR adds a new analytics event `not-found`. 

#### :heavy_check_mark: Checklist

<!--- Please include the following in your Pull Request when applicable: -->

- [x] A changeset describing the change and affected packages. ([more info](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#creating-changesets))

- [x] Tests for new functionality and regression tests for bug fixes
- [ ] Screenshots attached (for UI changes)
- [x] All your commits have a `Signed-off-by` line in the message. ([more info](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-certificate-of-origin))

issue.title: frontend-plugin-api: return output from extension factories instead

labels.name: area:catalog
labels.description: Related to the Catalog Project Area

labels.name: search
labels.description: Things related to Search

labels.name: area:discoverability
labels.description: Related to the Discoverability Project Area

issue.body:
## Hey, I just made a Pull Request!

Tbh this just feels way cleaner and I think we should try it 😅

The reason we did not design it like this to begin with is that it allows for more flexibility in the API evolution where we can provide multiple different arguments to the factory function and also deprecate old ones.

Except for being a bit more clear, we also hope that this will allow us to compose extension creation functions a bit better, since one factory can forward the outputs of another.

#### :heavy_check_mark: Checklist

<!--- Please include the following in your Pull Request when applicable: -->

- [x] A changeset describing the change and affected packages. ([more info](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#creating-changesets))

Tbh this just feels way cleaner and I think we should try it 😅

The reason we did not design it like this to begin with is that it allows for more flexibility in the API evolution where we can provide multiple different arguments to the factory function and also deprecate old ones.

Except for being a bit more clear, we also hope that this will allow us to compose extension creation functions a bit better, since one factory can forward the outputs of another.

issue.title: An `entityPresentationApiRef`, for rendering rich entity refs

labels.name: rfc
labels.description: Request For Comment(s)

labels.name: area:catalog
labels.description: Related to the Catalog Project Area

labels.name: area:scaffolder
labels.description: Everything and all things related to the scaffolder project area

issue.body:
## Summary

This adds an `entityPresentationApiRef` to the frontend, provided by the catalog, that lets you decide how to render entity refs in the Backstage user interface. This centralises whether to go by name, by title, by profile info, etc - even when extending the model with custom kinds. Its default implementation very efficiently batch fetches all required information from the catalog and caches it using a data loader, making the solution convenient and speedy, performing as few repaints as possible. The main consuming components are `EntityRefLink` and the new `EntityDisplayName` (which is the guts of the former, but without click behaviour).

![Screenshot 2023-04-20 at 22 46 06](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3097461/233483905-6a0ab0ce-2e6e-4c0b-b760-3411725c6184.png)

## Rationale

As discussed in [the catalog SIG](https://github.com/backstage/community/tree/main/sigs/sig-catalog), and asked for repeatedly through the life of the Backstage project, there is a need to consolidate how [entity refs](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/references) - pointers to entities and their names/titles - are rendered. Currently in the Backstage interface, most commonly we just render [the `metadata.name`](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#name-required) field, sometimes prefixed with [kind](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#apiversion-and-kind-required) and/or [namespace](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#namespace-optional). And the reason for doing so, is that at the point in time of actually rendering the ref, that's all the data we are holding in memory. Entities contain other fields that might have been more useful to the end user to display - for example a [title](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#title-optional) or the [display name](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#specprofile-optional-1) of a user's or group's profile info. And there is more information that could be interesting to glean as part of an entity reference, such as the [more granular type](https://backstage.io/docs/features/software-catalog/descriptor-format#spectype-required) of entity that it is, etc. But getting that data for display means a round trip to the catalog, and if every component did that fetch on its own it would severely delay rendering of the user interface and lead to lots of reinvention of the same code paths.

## Implementation

The default implementation of the API is basically [a Dataloader](https://github.com/graphql/dataloader) with a backing store that expires items after some time, and a never-expiring in-memory cache that can be used for instant paints of whatever information we have at hand while we refresh it in the background. The first time a ref link is rendered and no additional entity data is present, it'll paint a nice fallback based on only the ref itself while the framework streams in catalog data in the background. When it arrives, the presentation is reconsidered and a new paint may happen. The next time around, the entity will already be cached in memory and we can instantly render with the right representation. If enough time has passed since last time, the presentation API checks in the background whether the entity has changed since last time around and whether another paint is needed with the new information.

All fetching is memoized and batched, and only grabs the absolute minimum of fields of each entity that it needs to decide on the presentation, and always in the background. This makes them fast and never blocking renders.

## Future work

This API should be used everywhere where a reference to an entity is made. For example in the headers of pages, in nodes of entity graphs, etc etc. To help with that, an `EntityDisplayName` component was made which would be suitable e.g. in headers.

## Risks

- Using this API does mean that the Backstage interface will issue relatively frequent batch queries to the catalog, contributing to its load. However, the behavior can be disabled (replacing the implementation with one that doesn't call out to the catalog), and they are fairly lightweight since they only need partial data and only happen when client side caches are cold.
- This API does not have real time information from the catalog; there is an inherent delay between changes getting saved in the catalog and the API fetching back those changes to be reflected in the interface. This can be mitigated by setting the cache TTL to effectively zero, but that also increases the load on the catalog somewhat.
- The asynchronous fetching of data from the catalog means that repaints / relayouts sometimes happen in the interface, which can be disrupting. The placeholder that gets rendered while waiting for the data will probably not be shaped the same as the end state. After the cache gets hot, this generally becomes a non-issue since the next render will use the previously fetched entity to render a proper full presentation while double checking that it hasn't changed (which it extremely rarely has).

## Considerations for the reviewer

The interfaces need careful consideration here. The backing implementation isn't particularly complex or interesting I think, but the presentation type definitely is.

The two extremes probably is to either

- Expose only raw data, basically the plain entity and perhaps a single title-like string, or
- Going extremely "visual" and returning `React.ReactNode` or even `JSX.Element`, allowing absolutely anything at all

For example, the current implementation has a primary and secondary title, plus an icon. And it also returns the ref and entity as auxiliary information. But already, the secondary title feels limiting. Ideally it should be possible to seamlessly insert the usage of something like [the entity peek-ahead popover](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/15014) transparently around links, without the caller having to know exactly how it's formed. So all that is open for discussion really.

Note also that in the current design, renderers themselves can't be async. Ie you can't build a renderer that reaches out to an external system to get auxiliary data for the rendering. We could in theory make that possible, but we still need to retain the ability to instantly return results. I think it'd entail inverting control and putting more responsibility on the renderer itself, to make it work; it'd have to be the one that effectively "drives" the observable, rather than being called more than once. Or perhaps it could return an optional promise as part of its output, and the framework awaits that promise and sends its return value back to the renderer in the second call. Anyway, slight additional complexity, and could be added as a future feature without breaking interfaces, I think.

comment.body:
> > Feels like a great "Help Wanted" issue, I bet the Community would be more than happy to help given the number of issues asking for things to use the Title
> 
> Would it be possible to start this Help Wanted issue before the next release? So the next release ships with a bunch of these? :)

Feel free to create the issue any time! Or even better submit a PR with changes! 🚀

issue.title: 🚀 Feature: Make `fetch:plain` to allow fetching a single file instead of directory

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Help/Contributions wanted from community members

issue.body:
### 🔖 Feature description

Currently `fetch:plain` only allows to fetch directories, but for some cases it's useful to fetch individual files.

### 🎤 Context

We are utilizing scaffolds to automate service creation and as part of that we also open few MRs to a separate repository. We have a `CODEOWNERS` file in that repository and ideally we want to reduce manual actions and update that file with the team that has created a service.
I'm looking for a workflow like this:
```
    - id: fetch_codeowners
      name: Fetch CODEOWNERS from IaC
      action: fetch:plain
      input:
        url: https://gitlab.com/.../-/blob/main/CODEOWNERS
        targetPath: external/iac

    - id: update_codeowners
      name: Update CODEOWNERS
      action: miro:update-codeowners
      input:
        path: external/iac/CODEOWNERS
```

### ✌️ Possible Implementation

_No response_

### 👀 Have you spent some time to check if this feature request has been raised before?

- [X] I checked and didn't find similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Code of Conduct?

- [X] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

### Are you willing to submit PR?

No, but I'm happy to collaborate on a PR with someone else

comment.body: @vishal-singh3 No, `fetch:plain:file` is the one to use for individual files. I don't know about the format change, that sounds like it should be a separate ticket

issue.title: 🐛 Bug Report:  CORS policy: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body: ### 🔖 Need I have deployed Backstage on an Amazon Ubuntu machine, Website is loading but it is giving an Error:**Could not fetch catalog entities** and When I check the network tab it is giving cores ERROR Access to fetch at 'http:///api/catalog/entity-facets?facet=metadata.tags' from origin 'http://:3000' has been blocked by CORS policy: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. If an opaque response serves your needs, set the request's mode to 'no-cors' to fetch the resource with CORS disabled. Below is my **app-config.yaml** ``` app: title: Scaffolded Backstage App baseUrl: http://0.0.0.0:3000 organization: name: My Company backend: database: #auth: #keys: # - secret: ${BACKEND_SECRET} # config options: https://node-postgres.com/apis/client client: pg connection: host: 127.0.0.1 port: 5432 user: postgres password: secret # https://node-postgres.com/features/ssl # ssl: # host is only needed if the connection name differs from the certificate name. # This is for example the case with CloudSQL. # host: servername in the certificate # ca: # $file: /server.pem # key: # $file: /client.key # cert: # $file: /client-cert.pem # Used for enabling authentication, secret is shared by all backend plugins # See https://backstage.io/docs/auth/service-to-service-auth for # information on the format # auth: # keys: # - secret: ${BACKEND_SECRET} baseUrl: http://:80 listen: port: 80 # Uncomment the following host directive to bind to specific interfaces # host: 127.0.0.1 csp: connect-src: ["'self'", 'http:', 'https:'] # Content-Security-Policy directives follow the Helmet format: https://helmetjs.github.io/#reference # Default Helmet Content-Security-Policy values can be removed by setting the key to false cors: origin: http://:3000 methods: [GET, HEAD, PATCH, POST, PUT, DELETE] credentials: true Access-Control-Allow-Origin: '*' # This is for local development only, it is not recommended to use this in production # The production database configuration is stored in app-config.production.yaml #database: # client: better-sqlite3 # connection: ':memory:' # workingDirectory: /tmp # Use this to configure a working directory for the scaffolder, defaults to the OS temp-dir integrations: github: - host: github.com # This is a Personal Access Token or PAT from GitHub. You can find out how to generate this token, and more information # about setting up the GitHub integration here: https://backstage.io/docs/getting-started/configuration#setting-up-a-github-integration token: ### Example for how to add your GitHub Enterprise instance using the API: # - host: ghe.example.net # apiBaseUrl: https://ghe.example.net/api/v3 # token: ${GHE_TOKEN} auth: experimentalExtraAllowedOrigins: - 'http://:3000' # see https://backstage.io/docs/auth/ to learn about auth providers providers: github: development: clientId: clientSecret: ``` [ ](url) ### 🎉 Proposal I need help to solve this issue. I have tried multiple ways but nothing worked can you help me with this issue ### 〽️ Alternatives _No response_ ### ❌ Risks _No response_ ### 👀 Have you spent some time to check if this RFC has been raised before? - [X] I checked and didn't find similar issue ### 🏢 Have you read the Code of Conduct? - [X] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

pull_request.title: chore: fix spacing of header labels for entity layout
pull_request.body:
## Hey, I just made a Pull Request!
This PR adds an optional prop to the `HeaderLabel` component to specify the component type used in the content's parent `Typography` component.

This was done because this component is used in multiple places and in multiple conditions. When passed a string the `Typography` component used is `p`, for anything else we use `span`. The spacing between the component's label's `p` and content is different depending on if it is a `span` or another `p`.
In practice, any links passed into this component will have more spacing between the label and content. This is fine when the component is used elsewhere, and where that spacing is consistent. But when used in the header, and when right next to non-link sibling components, the spacing difference is obvious. 

By specifying that we want to use a `p` tag in this specific use for owner links inside `EntityLayout`, we can have the link and non-link items in the header have consistent spacing. 


<!-- Please describe what you added, and add a screenshot if possible.
     That makes it easier to understand the change so we can :shipit: faster. -->
### Changes
- add optional prop to `HeaderLabel` that sets `Typography` `component` prop
- use new prop in `EntityLayout`
- add tests

### Before (note spacing between label and content)
![SCR-20231023-l8s](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/assets/30599893/92ba7dcc-b8a6-499c-8a98-192e557ce126)

### After
![SCR-20231023-l8i](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/assets/30599893/fb163d01-e464-4212-a2c2-8e690ebf6313)


#### :heavy_check_mark: Checklist

<!--- Please include the following in your Pull Request when applicable: -->

- [ ] A changeset describing the change and affected packages. ([more info](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#creating-changesets))
- [ ] Added or updated documentation
- [x] Tests for new functionality and regression tests for bug fixes
- [x] Screenshots attached (for UI changes)
- [x] All your commits have a `Signed-off-by` line in the message. ([more info](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-certificate-of-origin))

comment.body: I was thinking more about having a `className` in the root `Typography` component and we can use CSS Grid or Flexbox to modify the spacing between child components (label and content) without necessarily forwarding a class to them. But I haven't tested the idea, so it's just a suggestion. What do you think @backstage/maintainers?

comment.body: I thought this `HeaderLabel` was created to be used only with page headers, and seeing it being used in entity cards seems like an opportunity to remove the `Header` prefix from the component name. But I don't have enough context about it and this refactor may not be necessary at this time or it can be done in a separate pull request. Let me ask the @backstage/maintainers what they think.

labels.name: area:techdocs

issue.body:
## Hey, I just made a Pull Request!

We're wanting to do some improvements, but first we want to get a baseline of how often a user ends up on a techdocs page that doesn't exist.

This PR adds a new analytics event `not-found`.
